metadata.case_name: Mysore State Road Transport Corporation v. Inter-State Operators
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 1755 to 1756 of 1969, 362 to 363 and 1918 to 1920 of 1970 and 490 to 492 of 1973; SLP Nos. 2015 to 2112 and 2408 to 2412 of 1969

facts.text: Three approved schemes for nationalisation under Chapter IVA of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939: Anekal Scheme dated 15-4-1959, Gulbarga Scheme dated 18-2-1960, and Bangalore Scheme dated 7-6-1960, covering certain intrastate routes in Mysore.
Parts of intrastate routes under the schemes overlap interstate routes over which private transporters were granted permits and renewals by State Transport authorities.
Mysore State Road Transport Corporation objects to these permits insofar as they cover overlapping portions of intrastate routes.
Regional Transport Officer granted or renewed permits to inter-state operators in some cases; in others, rejected but overturned by final State Appellate Authority.
Condition imposed by final Appellate Transport Authority on each inter-state operator: will neither pick up nor drop passengers on any part of the overlapping notified route.

Mysore High Court upheld grants of permits to inter-state operators in judgments dated 10th October 1968, 11th March 1969, 24th March 1969, 16th June 1969, and 11th November 1969, finding schemes ambiguous and not warranting total exclusion.
Twenty-two appeals by special leave and thirteen connected special leave petitions filed before Supreme Court.
Manager of appellant Corporation confined objections to sufficiency of buses on overlapping parts and did not rely on schemes for total prohibition.

Schemes published in official Gazette with particulars as per Mysore Gazette rules dated 27-2-1958, including routes with starting points, termini, intermediate stations, existing operators' names and trips.
Inter-state operators' names not mentioned in appended statements listing existing operators in the schemes.

legal_issues.text: Can a permit be granted to an Inter-State Transport Operator for the whole of his route despite the fact that a part of the route overlaps a part of a notified intra-State route?
Whether the schemes provide for partial or total exclusion of private operators, including inter-state operators from overlapping portions.
Whether Transport authorities have power to grant permits to inter-state operators with conditions prohibiting pick up/drop on overlapping notified routes, or if that modifies the schemes.

petitioner_arguments.text: Schemes under s.68C provide for exclusion, complete or partial, of other persons including inter-state operators from notified routes or portions thereof; transport authorities cannot deviate or modify approved schemes.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 s.68C, 68D, 68E; Nilkanth Prasad v. State of Bihar

petitioner_arguments.text: Route under Chapter IVA includes physical track; notification excludes private operators completely from sectors/routes vested in State Transport Undertaking.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Nilkanth Prasad v. State of Bihar; Kondala Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation

petitioner_arguments.text: Schemes warrant total exclusion of inter-state operators on overlapping parts; High Court erred in not allowing contention as it goes to jurisdiction.

respondent_arguments.text: Schemes ambiguous and do not clearly indicate total exclusion of inter-state operators from mere user/passage on overlapping portions; exclusion only for services between termini on notified routes.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Motor Vehicles Act s.68C requires clear particulars; Mysore Rules 1958 require naming existing operators

respondent_arguments.text: Inter-state operators not named in schemes' lists of existing operators, so not intended to be excluded; could not object as affected persons.
Conditions imposed (no pick/drop) align with schemes; Corporation's Manager impliedly admitted no total prohibition by objecting only to sufficiency.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: H.C. Narayanappa v. State of Mysore

court_reasoning.text: State Transport Undertaking has power under s.68C to exclude even inter-state operators from part of notified route, but scheme must make intention clear; mere physical overlap insufficient without unequivocal language.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Route is line of travel between termini (post-1969 def. s.2(28A)); nationalisation of services, not highway surfaces.

court_reasoning.text: Schemes' preambles and clauses 3-7 do not indicate total exclusion; refer to routes by termini, list only intra-state operators; inter-state not named, so reasonable inference they are not excluded from passage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Anekal, Gulbarga, Bangalore schemes examined; omission of inter-state names supports non-exclusion.

court_reasoning.text: Transport authorities can impose conditions consistent with schemes; no modification as conditions enforce no service on notified portions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Conditions rightly imposed to reflect scheme meaning.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Nilkanth Prasad as pre-definition of route and different context; follows Narayanappa interpreting Anekal scheme.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Schemes cover services between specified termini, not mere passage.

holdings.text: Approved schemes do not prohibit inter-state operators from using overlapping portions of notified intra-state routes without picking up/dropping passengers thereon.
Schemes are not of total exclusion extending to mere user by inter-state operators on overlapping parts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nilkanth Prasad Ors. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished on definition of route pre-s.2(28A); not applicable to these schemes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Standard Motor Union Pvt Ltd. v. State of Kerala Ors
precedents_cited.relevance: Power under s.68C includes excluding inter-state operators from part of route.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Abdul Khader Saheb v. Mysore Revenue Appellate Tribunal Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Power under s.68C to exclude inter-state operators.

precedents_cited.case_name: Saghir Ahmed Anr. v. State of U.P. Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Public right to use highways anterior to Act; State regulates but right to passage exists.

precedents_cited.case_name: H.C. Narayanappa Ors. v. State of Mysore Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Interpreted Anekal scheme; route refers to service between termini, not blanket prohibition on portions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kondala Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corporation
precedents_cited.relevance: Whether route can be area; distinguished in Nilkanth.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kelani Valley Motor Transit Co. v. Colombo Ratnapura Omnibus Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Route as abstract line between termini, distinguished in Nilkanth.

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Framing, approval, modification of nationalisation schemes; requires particulars including routes by termini; power to exclude but must be clear.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore State Road Transport Undertaking Rules, 1958
statutes_cited.relevance: Prescribed particulars for schemes: routes with termini, existing operators' names/trips, etc.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals and special leave petitions, upholding the Mysore High Court's decisions granting/renewing permits to inter-state operators over overlapping portions of notified routes, subject to no pick-up/drop conditions, as schemes do not clearly prohibit mere passage.
outcome.relief_granted: Permits to inter-state operators upheld with conditions.

key_quotes.text: "Can a permit be granted to an Inter-State Transport Operator for the whole of his route despite the fact that a part of the route overlaps a part of a notified intra-State route?"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Formulates the common question of law.

key_quotes.text: "Unless a scheme clearly indicates that the user of every portion of a highway covered by an intrastate notified route is prohibited also to an inter-state motor vehicle operator... the inter-state operator may not be completely debarred."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key principle for interpreting exclusion in schemes.

key_quotes.text: "The interpretation of the three schemes advanced on behalf of the inter-state operators is more reasonable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
